comment.author: 92442038@N00
comment._content: Cockwiln: you are right, old does not make it this a masterpiece. However, the distance in age between this picture and today's photographic culture tells us a great deal about our era. So beyond the questionable aesthetic features of this picture, this is a good historic shot whose qualities lie more in what it can show us about contemporary photos (and its material institution) than its lacks of -your implied judgement- artistic features.

comment._content:
Well, apparently from reading the info at the link provided by Pixel Wrangler, she is dressed for performing arts related photos. That explains the apparel in this shot and the one at the link.
I do really like this shot. People can complain all they want... I care more about the subject than the quality when it comes to these old photographs. To me it's about connecting with history, not about quality photography.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content:
hairsoplenty - it is a background! This is not an image done in photoshop ... it's an original glass plate  from a reputed museum collection ... I've personally looked at some of these original plates ... it's just vintage photography ... you are looking at it from a 21st century eye without understanding old photographs and 'simple' techniques like backdrops. 

PS agreed the notes look crappy but it is a good interactive way to engage with the image  and other users

comment.author: 73368734@N00
comment._content: This young lady was quite scandalous in her day -- photos like these were considered to be on the milder end of the pornography spectrum!  There's a second layer of scandal here as well, since only men wore kilts.  Women would wear a similar garment called a kilted skirt that fastened on the opposite side, and without the sporran.  A woman being photographed in a kilt (and a shockingly short one at that!) with a sporran would be the equivalent of a woman posing in a jockstrap today.
